misconceptions.name: Misinterpreting the problem requirements (solving a different problem)
misconceptions.description: The student wrote a program to compute average acceleration from initial velocity, final velocity, and time, instead of summing the even numbers among five input integers as required. This indicates a misunderstanding or disregard of the actual problem specification.
misconceptions.student_belief: I need to write a program that reads v0, v1, and t as doubles and computes the average acceleration (v1 - v0) / t.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should read exactly 5 integers from the user, check which of them are even (n % 2 == 0), accumulate the sum of only those even numbers, and then print that sum.
symptoms: Program prompt asks for 'v0, v1, and t' instead of '5 integers'.
Program reads three double values instead of five integers.
There is no loop to process 5 separate inputs.
There is no conditional check for even numbers using modulus (n % 2 == 0).
The output reports 'average acceleration' instead of 'sum of even numbers'.
misconceptions.root_cause: The student appears to have reused or focused on a different physics-related problem (average acceleration) instead of implementing the specified task to sum even numbers from five integers.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem carefully and restate it in your own words before coding. Then design the algorithm: read 5 integers, loop over them, use an if-condition to check if each number is even (n % 2 == 0), add even numbers to a running total, and finally print the sum with the required message.
related_concepts: Mapping problem statements to program design
Input specification (number and type of inputs)
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The entire program consistently implements an acceleration calculation problem and contains no elements related to reading 5 integers, checking evenness, or summing them, so it is almost certain the student addressed the wrong task.

evidence.note: This code reads three double values (v0, v1, t) and computes average acceleration, rather than reading five integers, checking which are even, and summing the even ones.

misconceptions.name: Complete Misinterpretation of Assignment Requirements
misconceptions.description: The student submitted a program that calculates average acceleration, which is a solution for a separate problem, and does not address the required task of finding the sum of 5 even numbers.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to have submitted code for an entirely different assignment (calculating average acceleration) instead of the required program for finding the sum of even numbers.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The task required reading 5 integers, using a loop structure, applying a conditional check (modulus operator) to identify even numbers, and accumulating their sum.
symptoms: Code asks for 'v0, v1, and t'
Calculates average acceleration using a formula
Does not use any looping structure
Does not check for even numbers
misconceptions.root_cause: Misunderstanding the prompt or submitting the incorrect file for the assignment.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Please ensure the code submitted corresponds directly to the problem prompt. Start by establishing a loop structure to read 5 inputs and an accumulator variable set to zero.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The class name, print statements, variable names, and core logic all definitively point to a different assignment (acceleration calculation).

evidence.note: The entire program implements the logic for calculating average acceleration, completely ignoring the stated goal of summing 5 even numbers.

misconceptions.name: Wrong Problem Solved - Acceleration Calculator Instead of Sum of Even Numbers
misconceptions.description: The student has written a program to calculate average acceleration using the formula (v1 - v0) / t, which is completely different from the required task of reading 5 integers and summing only the even numbers.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe they are solving a physics problem about acceleration, not a programming exercise about filtering and summing even numbers.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The task requires reading exactly 5 integers from user input, checking which ones are even (n % 2 == 0), and printing the sum of only those even numbers. The example shows: 3 8 2 7 4 → sum is 8 + 2 + 4 = 14.
symptoms: Program reads 3 double values instead of 5 integers
Program performs division operation instead of modulo check
Program calculates acceleration instead of filtering even numbers
Output is completely different from expected output
misconceptions.root_cause: Fundamental misunderstanding of the assignment requirements. The student may have confused this problem with a different assignment or failed to read the problem statement carefully.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement carefully. You need to: (1) Read 5 integers using a loop, (2) Check if each number is even using (n % 2 == 0), (3) Add even numbers to a running sum, (4) Print the sum. Start over with the correct problem in mind.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Extremely high confidence - the submitted code solves an entirely different problem (physics acceleration) compared to the assigned problem (sum of even numbers). This is not a minor error but a fundamental misalignment with the assignment.

evidence.note: Program reads 3 doubles and calculates acceleration, completely ignoring the requirement to read 5 integers and sum even numbers.
Output format and content do not match the required output format (Sum of even numbers: 14)

misconceptions.name: Implemented acceleration calculator instead of summing even numbers
misconceptions.description: The student wrote a program that computes average acceleration from three double inputs (v0, v1, t) instead of reading five integers and summing only the even ones as required.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes the task is to read starting and final velocity and time, then compute and print the average acceleration using the physics formula (v1 - v0) / t.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should read exactly five integers from the user, use a conditional check (n % 2 == 0) to identify even numbers, accumulate only those even numbers into a running sum, and then print the sum of the even numbers.
symptoms: Reads three double values instead of five integers.
No loop is used to process multiple inputs.
No modulo (%) or even-number check appears in the code.
Output message describes average acceleration instead of sum of even numbers.
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely confusion between different example problems (e.g., a textbook acceleration example) or not carefully reading the current assignment requirements.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Discard the acceleration-specific code and re-read the question. Implement a loop that reads 5 integers, check each with n % 2 == 0, add the even ones to a sum variable, and finally print the sum in the requested format.
related_concepts: Mapping problem statements to program structure
Looping over a fixed number of inputs
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The entire program is structured around an acceleration formula example with no sign of reading 5 integers or summing even numbers, indicating a clear mismatch with the prompt.

evidence.note: Code reads three doubles labeled v0, v1, t and computes average acceleration, with no logic for reading 5 integers or summing even numbers.

misconceptions.name: Complete Misinterpretation of Assignment Goal
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a program to calculate average acceleration based on three floating-point inputs (v0, v1, t), completely ignoring the assignment requirement to calculate the sum of five even integers.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes the task was to write a program for an 'Acceleration Calculator', not a 'Sum of Even Numbers' program, indicating a failure to read and understand the prompt for Q1.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The correct task was to read 5 integers and accumulate the sum of only the even numbers among them.
symptoms: Code has logic for acceleration calculation
Code asks for 'v0, v1, and t'
Code reads three doubles instead of five integers
No loop or conditional logic (modulo check) related to even numbers
misconceptions.root_cause: Misreading the assignment prompt and implementing code intended for a different, likely previous, problem template ('Acceleration Calculator' is a common introductory problem).
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Carefully reread the assignment requirement for Q1: 'Sum of Even Numbers'. Delete the acceleration calculation logic and replace it with a loop to read 5 integers, use an if statement with the modulus operator to check for evenness, and accumulate the sum.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The provided code is entirely dedicated to solving a physics problem (average acceleration) and contains none of the elements required for the 'Sum of Even Numbers' problem (loop 5 times, check for evenness, accumulator). This is a definitive misinterpretation.

evidence.note: The entire program calculates acceleration, not the sum of even numbers. This demonstrates a complete misunderstanding of the required task.

misconceptions.name: Incorrect Number of Inputs and Data Type Mismatch
misconceptions.description: The student reads only 3 inputs and attempts to read them as `double`s instead of reading 5 inputs specifically as integers, which is necessary for the even number check using the modulus operator.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes that reading three double values fulfills the input requirements for the assigned problem.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment required reading 5 distinct numerical inputs, specifically integers, using a loop structure.
symptoms: Uses nextDouble()
Reads only three variables
No looping structure to handle 5 inputs
misconceptions.root_cause: The input reading logic is tied to the incorrect overall goal (acceleration calculation) rather than the required Q1 goal.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Change `nextDouble()` calls to `nextInt()`. Ensure a mechanism (like a `for` loop) is used to read exactly five values.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code explicitly calls `nextDouble()` three times instead of using a loop with `nextInt()` five times.

evidence.note: Reads three inputs as doubles instead of five inputs as integers.

misconceptions.name: Problem Misinterpretation - Completely Wrong Problem
misconceptions.description: The student has solved an entirely different problem. The submission calculates average acceleration from velocities (a physics problem: a = (v1 - v0) / t) instead of summing even numbers from user input. This indicates fundamental misunderstanding of the assignment requirements.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe this assignment asks them to calculate average acceleration given initial velocity, final velocity, and time elapsed.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment requires reading exactly 5 integers, identifying which ones are even (divisible by 2 with no remainder), summing only those even numbers, and printing the sum. For example: input [3, 8, 2, 7, 4] should output 14 (8 + 2 + 4).
symptoms: Code reads 3 values instead of 5
Code reads doubles instead of integers
Code calculates a velocity/acceleration formula instead of filtering and summing
Code output format doesn't match expected output
No loop or conditional logic for the actual problem
misconceptions.root_cause: The student submitted code for a completely different assignment/problem, suggesting either a copy-paste error, working on the wrong problem, or fundamental misunderstanding of which assignment they were completing.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement carefully. The task is to: (1) create a loop that reads 5 integers, (2) use an if condition to check if each number is even using `number % 2 == 0`, (3) add even numbers to a sum variable, (4) print the final sum. Start from scratch with this clear understanding.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Very high confidence because this is not a minor logic error—the entire code solves a fundamentally different problem with different input types, different formula, different output format, and an entirely different domain (physics vs. number processing).

evidence.note: Reads 3 physics variables instead of 5 integers; calculates acceleration formula instead of summing even numbers
Output format is completely incorrect for the assignment; should output sum of even numbers, not acceleration
